author: 3xmd1559sporebraytondingo
content: EIP-2200 is Final, EIP-1283 is Final, and EIP-1706 is Withdrawn. Did EIP-1283 get "included on it's own merits", or did it "inherit it's inclusion" from EIP-2200?

author: axic3354
content: The `Final` status doesn't mean inclusion anywhere, just that the text of the EIP cannot change.

author: axic3354
content: Though admittedly throughout the years these rules were interpreted differently, however there was either a "hardfork meta eip" for listing included EIPs, and now there is the execution-specs repo doing so.

author: axic3354
content: Regarding 2200, the abstract states `This is a combination of EIP-1283 and EIP-1706.`  and the EIP doesn't list a dependency in the preamble, so I assume it should be read in isolation without the need for either 1283 nor 1706.

author: gcolvin
content:
> The Final status doesn't mean inclusion anywhere, just that the text of the EIP cannot change.

> Though admittedly throughout the years these rules were interpreted differently

Once upon a time <@!492808720615604251> argued strongly and <@!191378736254287874> and I agreed that Final was the last Draft before the EIP went on the mainnet -- because whatever was on the mainnet was the reality.  Any changes to the text after that were Errata.  Draft and Final were the only two statuses for a Core EIP.  Then things got complicated ... ðŸ˜‰

author: sky.cactus
content: For Core EIPs this still holds for the most part.  For Core EIPs Last Call is entered prior to hitting public testnets, and Final is reached after going live on mainnet.

author: sky.cactus
content: For non Core EIPs things are different.

author: axic3354
content: It actually was called `Accepted`. EIPs had to be in that state for a protocol update, and moved to `Final` afterwards, given final ones can't be changed.

author: gcolvin
content: I'm speaking of a time before that, when we were choosing to adhere to the IETF process with only two statuses: Draft and Internet Standard.  Our attitude was that the Core Devs could do whatever they wanted with (or without) a Draft at any time, and it was none of the EIP Editors business.  I think things got complicated when the core devs started using the editorial status of the EIP to track its status in the ever-changing and ill-defined development process.  I think that was a mistake, and would have preferred a separate field the header for that purpose.

author: axic3354
content: I think the `Accepted` status was there from the very beginning?

author: gcolvin
content: For the Core Devs, maybe so.  I'm only recalling our original intent.

author: axic3354
content: Going back to commit 1012b44f490e1950d0294ffe4a5df500837f68ae (from Oct 2015), `eip-1.mediawiki` has the accepted status listed ðŸ™‚

author: gcolvin
content: Then I guess it goes way back.  The Core Devs started using that field, and we three Editors went along with it.  So be it.
